docs.lead_paragraph: Newt Gingrich’s campaign published a Web page addressing potential lightning rods for his candidacy.

headline.seo: Newt Gingrich Site Seeks to Allay Conservatives’ Fears
headline.main: Gingrich Site Seeks to Allay Conservatives’ Fears
headline.print_headline: Gingrich Site Seeks to Allay Conservatives’ Fears

docs.abstract: Newt Gingrich releases a message on his Web page addressing potential lightning rods for his candidacy for the party activists who will be crucial to his hopes of winning his party’s nomination; he is seeking to avoid the plight of those in the Republican race who have risen before him, only to plummet under scrutiny.
docs.snippet: Newt Gingrich’s campaign published a Web page addressing potential lightning rods for his candidacy.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Census Bureau’s new formulas offer a broader picture of poverty, and evidence that programs to aid the poor work.
docs.abstract: Editorial asserts that the new and improved gauge of poverty released by the Census Bureau shows that the number of Americans just above the poverty line is larger than previously believed; argues that the new numbers make a compelling case for pursuing government policies that help the poor and boost the economy.
docs.snippet: The Census Bureau’s new formulas offer a broader picture of poverty, and evidence that programs to aid the poor work.

docs.lead_paragraph: Roman Catholic bishops, charities, schools and universities are seeking a broad exemption for employers who object to covering free birth control for women for moral and religious reasons.

headline.seo: Democrats Urge Obama to Defend Birth Control Rules
headline.main: Democrats Urge Obama to Protect Contraceptive Coverage in Health Plans
headline.print_headline: Democrats Urge Obama to Protect Contraceptive Coverage in Health Plans

docs.abstract: Roman Catholic bishops, charities, schools and universities are seeking a broad exemption for employers who object to covering free birth control for women for moral and religious reasons from new rules for health insurance plans; White House is weighing proposal that would expand the exemption to many universities, hospitals, clinics and other entities associated with religious organizations; many Democrats object to change.
docs.snippet: Roman Catholic bishops, charities, schools and universities are seeking a broad exemption for employers who object to covering free birth control for women for moral and religious reasons.

headline.seo: Remedy And Reaction - The Peculiar American Struggle Over Health Care Reform - By Paul Starr - Book Review

docs.abstract: Timothy Noah reviews book Remedy and Reaction: The Peculiar American Struggle Over Health Care Reform by Paul Starr.
docs.snippet: Paul Starr examines the history behind the health policy choices of the Obama administration.

docs.lead_paragraph: ON a typical night in the emergency room, a patient shows up short of breath, suffering from emphysema or heart failure or maybe both, as well as diabetes and high blood pressure. Doctors and nurses administer inhalers to ease his breathing and diuretics to take off excess fluid, and admit him to the hospital. Over the next few days, interns and residents furiously adjust his medications and fix his diet. He is discharged with a stack of prescriptions. A week or two later, chances are good he'll be right back in the emergency room. A 2009 study in The New England Journal of Medicine showed that among Medicare patients, 20 percent were re-admitted to the hospital within 30 days of being discharged. We call these chronically ill patients frequent fliers.
docs.abstract: Ezekiel J Emanuel Op-Ed column argues that changing the way chronically ill patients are cared for would result in dramatic savings in the cost of health care for everyone; asserts that these savings can be achieved by making care for the chronically ill better, not worse, and by changing the way patients and insurers pay for that care. Drawing (M)i

docs.abstract: The Census Bureau’s new measure of poverty casts light on the large number of Americans living just above the line. Four residents of the Washington, D.C., area tell how they cope.
docs.snippet: The Census Bureau’s new measure of poverty casts light on the large number of Americans living just above the line. Four residents of the Washington, D.C., area tell how they cope.

byline.original: By SABRINA TAVERNISE, JASON DEPARLE and ROBERT GEBELOFF

docs.lead_paragraph: When the Census Bureau this month released a new measure of poverty, meant to better count disposable income, it began altering the portrait of national need.
docs.abstract: A closer look at a new definition of poverty casts new light on the large number of Americans living just above the poverty line. Four residents of the Washington, D.C., area who fall into that group tell how they are coping.
docs.snippet: A closer look at a new definition of poverty casts new light on the large number of Americans living just above the poverty line. Four residents of the Washington, D.C., area who fall into that group tell how they are coping.

byline.original: By SABRINA TAVERNISE, JASON DEPARLE and ROBERT GEBELOFF

docs.lead_paragraph: The Census Bureau’s new measure of poverty adjusts for cost of living and includes government benefits and income lost to taxes, health care and work expenses.
docs.snippet: The Census Bureau’s new measure of poverty adjusts for cost of living and includes government benefits and income lost to taxes, health care and work expenses.
